captions.text:
That's not the kind
of upbringing, l guess,
is the word l'm looking for.

lt's not the kind of man
you are. l understand that.

l'm not looking to humiliate
you or exact a price
in any way,

so why don't you
just apologize?

We'll call it water under
the dam, and we'll go
about our business.

Excuse me,
what the fuck?

What?
What the fuck
are you talking about?

Clair George said you
were coming in here
to apologize.

No, l'm supposed to come
in here so you could
apologize to me.

According to whom?
Clair George.

You told me to go fuck myself.
l'm supposed to apologize
to you?

Also, water goes over
a dam and under a bridge,
you poncy schoolboy.

Clearly there's been
a miscommunication between
Clair George and somebody.

Excuse me.
Yes?

Does this look all right?
It's fine.

Thank you.
l can sand it
down a little.

l, l don't know.
l have no fucking idea
who this guy is.

He is here to fix the glass
that you broke the last time
you were here.

Could you just excuse us
for a second there?
Yes.

You tell me to go
fuck myself

and l'm supposed
to apologize?
You break my window,

l'm supposed to apologize?
The Helsinki job was mine!

The Helsinki job was not
yours. If it was yours,
you'd be in Helsinki.

Alan Wolfe stood
in this office!
Alan Wolfe

is no longer the Director.
Yeah, it was on the books!

Alan Wolfe is no
Ionger the Director
of European Operations.

He does not make
those appointments. l do.

Promises were made.
Not by me.

l've been with
the company for 24 years.

l was posted
in Greece for 15.

Papandreou wins that election
if l don't help the junta
take him prisoner.

l've advised and armed
the Hellenic army.

l've neutralized
champions of Communism.

l've spent the past
three years learning
Finnish!

Which should come in handy
here in Virginia!

And l'm never,
ever, sick at sea.

So l want to know
why l'm not gonna be
your Helsinki station chief.

You're coarse.
Excuse me?

For Helsinki, l need someone
with diplomatic skills.

You don't have them.
Is that right?

That is right. And l
don't know why the hell
l didn't fire you

when you broke
my fucking window!

Oh, yes, sure
you do, Cravely.

Look, Gust...
Yeah, you're fucking
Roger's fiancĂŠe
and you know l know.

l'm not... l'm not even
gonna dignify that with
a response.

Yeah, yeah, you're
dignifying her in the ass

at the Jefferson Hotel,
room 1 210.

But let me ask you.
The 3,OOO agents
Turner fired

was that because they lacked
diplomatic skills as well?

You're referring
to Admiral Stansfield Turner?
Yeah, the 3,OOO agents.

Each and every goddamn one
of them first or second
generation Americans.

ls that because they lack
the proper diplomatic skills?

Or did Turner not
think it was a good idea
to have spies

who could speak the
same language as the people
they're fucking spying on?

Well, l'm sorry,
but you can hardly
blame the Director

for questioning the loyalty
to America of people that
are just barely Americans

in the first place.
Yeah, well, l'd like
to take a moment

to review the several ways
in which you're a douchebag.

Get the fuck
out of my office!
Yes, sir.

Before l end
your career, asshole.
Yes, sir!

Yeah, my friend,
l'm gonna need
you for a second.
(WOMAN SCREAMS)
God damn it!
My loyalty?

For 24 years,
people have been
trying to kill me.
People who know how.

Now, do you think that's
because my dad was
a Greek soda pop maker

or do you think that's
because l'm an American spy?

Go fuck yourself,
you fucking child.
How was l?
Thank you.

title: Charlie Wilson's War (1/9) Movie CLIP - Another Broken Window (2007) HD

comments.text: Your Course. AHHAHAHAHA﻿
comments.author: Don Swain

comments.text:
This movie is awesome! I recommend everyone to watch it. Its storyline 
(specially its ending) helps understand how USA's actions in *Russia-occupied 
Afghanistan* contributed to USA's victory in the *cold war* against Russia 
but, as a side effect, also contributed to the rise of the *Taliban*, which 
later would become the agent of the *9/11 attacks* and the initial reason 
for the onset of USA's "war against terrorism".

USA's governmental decision to suppress the last part of its foreign policy 
plan for the Afghanistan is a strong indication that USA *put an end to a 
war but helped the onset of another one*. Chronologically:

*1*) USA beats Russia in Afghanistan. This puts an end to the "cold war".

*2*) Satisfied to have won the "cold war", USA doesn't help post-russian 
occupation Afghanistan to recover: no schools are built, no hospitals, no 
democratic elections are stimulated, neither the development of a laic 
State and laic Constitution. USA just leaves the territory of a very 
weakened Afghanistan that can't deal with the rising Taliban.

*3*) A while after, Taliban becomes a powerful terrorist group and causes 
the 9/11 attacks.

*4*) As a late reaction, USA declares war on terrorism.

*Charlie Wilson's War* tells the story from the moment Russia occupies 
Afghanistan until *2* (when USA leaves Afghanistan free from Russia but 
alone, trying to recover from war and deal with its internal problems, 
Taliban included). Very worth watching movie!﻿
comments.author: Yuri Sucupira

comments.text:
+Jeremy Kyle Super Fan (Irish Retard Army)

comments.author: Yuri Sucupira

comments.text:
+Yuri Sucupira I felt some water in my eyes when Charlie was talking about

goes - "Who gives a damn about Pakistan?!" And then he slowly responds 
"...It is Afghanistan..."
comments.author: Jeremy Kyle Super Fan (Irish Retard Army)

comments.text:
+Jeremy Kyle Super Fan (Irish Retard Army) Yep, I do (think the US 
should've helped rebuild Afghanistan). Imo, if they did this, this would've 
probably avoided the 9/11 attacks and also promoted the establishment of a 
US ally in the Greater Middle East. Terrorism spread all over the Greater 
Middle East because no one cared about none of these countries until it was 
too late to do anything about it.

The problem was blindness: at the time, the US only cared about defeating 
Russia. They didn't see the bigger picture.

I like how in the final part of this movie you can hear the sound of a jet 
airliner (a clear reference to the 9/11 attacks) right after Gus tells 
Charlie Wilson to listen to what he's telling him:

*watch?v=e2cjVhUrmII&t=2m*
comments.author: Yuri Sucupira

comments.text:
+Yuri Sucupira Do you think the US should have helped rebuild Afghanistan 
in 1989? The ending made me feel kind of sad. They mostly only cared about 
taking down Russia's empire.

L'indimenticabile Philip Seymour Hoffman è l’agente della CIA Gus Avrakotos

afgani contro gli invasori russi.
Nella versione italiana Hoffman è doppiato in maniera efficace da Francesco 
Pannofino.﻿

comments.author: DrumNUT

comments.text:
+Mark Eleison  Lane dismisses the idea that Hoffman is doing anything so 
'vulgar' as 'breaking the fourth wall' in that scene, asserting instead 
that it's an example of how people put on 'performances' in real life. I'm 
not so sure though .. perhaps Nichols knew he had an average film on his 
hands with an exceptional actor in the middle of it, and this was his 
somewhat subversive means of acknowledging as much to the viewer. Either 
way, it was his call. Even if they did go off-script it couldn't have been 
entirely improvised, as it required blocking, different camera and boom 
work, and a response from the other actor. It's testament to Hoffman's 
abilities that such dimensions would even be considered in a lousy movie.

He's brilliant in that basketball scene ("Along Came Polly".) As great as 
he was in "The Master" or deserving of the Oscar for "Capote," I think I 
preferred him in the supporting roles where he'd show up and relegate the 
star to the role of mere celebrity.
comments.author: ocan1033

comments.text:
+ocan1033 Yes, it definitely was Lane's piece, as I mentioned, that made me 
go back and look more closely at what Hoffman was doing in these scenes, 
and certainly I was merely carrying the mail for him.  I do take some 
exception to your writing that I called Mike Nichols a "narcissistic 
filmmaker". (I'd forgotten Nichols directed it!) I referred in the 
aggregate to the "filmmakers' narcissism", not to the director alone. And 
you make the very good point that Nichols left the line in the film. So 
maybe that was his way of finessing a sophomoric script? It would be 
interesting to know, wouldn't it, whose idea was it for the coda to that 
scene: Hoffman or Nichols. Either one though, I still bet it wasn't in the 
script.
     Yes, Boogie Nights was a very good movie, and Hoffman is almost too 
painful to watch. But then as brutal as that scene was, look at him in 
Along Came Polly. When was that, ten years ago? I still hear him in my 
head, tossing up bricks and screaming "Let it Rain!" and I laugh at loud, 
apropos of nothing.  Yeah, you said it: he ALWAYS delivered the goods.
comments.author: Mark Eleison

comments.text:
+Mark Eleison Well, yes .. that's kind of Anthony Lane's point in the New 
Yorker piece. And while it's not a very good movie, it's interesting to 
note that the 'narcissistic filmmaker' in question - Mike Nichols - chose 
to leave the line in the film. But Hoffman seemed to do that with all his 
roles, whether the films were deserving or not. Look at the scene in Boogie 
Nights (a good film) where he is rebuffed by Mark Wahlberg and sits crying 
in his car. There's that moment just after he's been on camera when you 
kind of sit in awe thinking "what was that?"
comments.author: ocan1033

comments.text:
+CHUUUUify No, you've missed the point. Of course Cravely is "an Idiot," 
also a supercilious prick. The script has hit you over the head with it, 
clued you how to react to his dressing down by Gus: he's got it coming. (In 
fact the whole movie is a smug, presumptuous, 
self-congratulatory love-letter to itself, rife with intelligence-insulting 
 tripwires.) But Hoffman has overcome the filmmakers narcissism 
by indicating the narcissism in his character, which I doubt was in the 
script. That's the point of the ending, and another example how Hoffman
infuses all his characters with dead-on realness. That is why he's a great 
actor.
comments.author: Mark Eleison

comments.text:
"How'd I do?" or something like that. and patting the typewriter? well, 
he's thanking her for her thumbs up, obviously. If she were out from behind 
the desk, he might have patted her on the butt. It's a beautiful end to 
that scene. I mean, who hasn't done something like this and felt as if one 
were on stage? All is vanity, right? Read Anthony Lane's piece in the 
on-line New Yorker about these exquisite artistic  touches of Seymour's. 
And I will echo Lane's lament : What have we lost with his passing!
comments.author: Mark Eleison

comments.author: Bachishaman

comments.text:
Oh, I KNOW, eh?   I can't criticize one single thing about Hoffman's 
performance there, but if I had edited it, the window smash would've taken 
only one heavy blow, and Slattery's flinch would have been perfectly in 
time with the smash, or JUST late, as the shards flew inward. 

Now, I realize that glass can be very resilient.  In fact, a few years ago 
when I watched as my condo burned to the ground from the street, I saw my 
cousin try to smash the passenger-side window of his car that was in the 
driveway because, since he left his keys inside the inferno and we barely 
escaped with our lives, he wanted to put it in neutral and get it to safety 
before the burning debris destroyed it too - it took him three or four 
HEAVY "stabs" with a 20 pound iron bench-press bar he grabbed from the open 
garage before it finally shattered.

So yeah...my only criticism is from the people in post, is what I'm 
saying.  That was the most epic "Ratta-tat-tat!" machine gun fire of an 
insult, and yet we see an additional unsuccessful attempt at the "epic 
cool" window smash, which comes off a little more like "frustration" than 
it does "TOTAL FUCKING BADASS."  

Granted, his character is OBVIOUSLY frustrated, but...you know what I 
mean.  If a person were to fantasize about telling off THEIR boss, would it 
take them THREE hits to smash his window?  Or to knock him out cold with an 
uppercut? 

Of course not.

Just one. 

RIP, Phillip Seymour Hoffman 

Hollywood is going to suck quite a bit (more) without the talent he used to 
improve it.  : /

(Edit: THREE hits - I originally said TWO.  Even worse! Heh heh)
comments.author: johnnytastetest

comments.author: Stephen Allen

comments.text:
You need multiple hands to count the number of movies where Hoffman has, in 
a matter of minutes, effortlessly walked away with the most memorable scene 
in a movie. One of the greatest actors in the history of American cinema. 
An incalculable loss to the movies.﻿

comments.author: Shawn K.

comments.text:
+Sean D A book about what? Is there a book you recommend about how sticking 
a needle in your arm is a virtue? Or a book that says cancer is as 
avoidable as heroin?

Nobody chooses to be an addict? Even when he put the needle in his arm? 
You're therefore stating cancer is like putting a needle in your arm. Maybe 
you should go to a hospital and ask a dying cancer patient "Why? Didn't you 
know it was bad for you?" Cancer patients don't choose to have that in 
their bodies, as you've just said.

I'm not entirely sure you actually comprehended what you said. Please, 
correct yourself. 

Well I for one don't believe life to be a convenience. Then again, this 
topic isn't about God is it? I'm sure you try and spit on others at every 
turn but lets try keeping to the subject, alright?
comments.author: Just Joshin

comments.text:
+Ian Haim So you measure the worth of a person by their ability to pretend 
to be someone else?
comments.author: Just Joshin

comments.text:
+Ian Haim High horse? I have to be on a high horse to condemn harming 
yourself with dangerous drugs? There is nobody who makes all good choices 
but this man meant nothing to you other than seeing him on film, acting. He 
wasn't a relative, a friend, or even an acquaintance. He killed himself 
using drugs. It's sad yeah, but it's not any sadder than anyone else who 
abuses their bodies with drugs. And the only thing sadder than someone 
dying because of their OWN choices is someone dying because of outside 
events brought upon them. So sympathy is better spent elsewhere. Not on 
druggies you didn't know. Let his loved ones cry for him. He's not special 
because he pretended to be someone else on screen.
comments.author: Just Joshin

comments.text:
+Kyle Mercutio

Well your just swell, bet you go through life making no mistakes or bad 
decisions.
Fact is you dont know this mans personal life or state of mind off screen, 
so get off your high horse and show some fucking respect.
comments.author: Ian Haim

comments.text:
No one gives a shit about the "Other Heroin Addicts"
Dont even compare them to this talented man, its an insult to his memory.
comments.author: Ian Haim

comments.text:
+David Bulgarelli Understand? Nobody forced him to jam a needle in his arm. 
Sympathy is better spent on people who get killed by things out of there 
control. Hoffman made his bed and died in it. 

Yeah, I'd rather be "that guy", aka the only one who isn't a mindless sheep 
herded into worship of celebrities.
